description: Dive into "Capturing Dresden: A Photographer's Journey" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Capturing Dresden: A Photographer's Journey

places.generalDescription: Dresden Zwinger is a stunning Baroque building that houses a porcelain collection and exhibits on historic scientific instruments. The city of Dresden, often referred to as 'The Florence on the Elbe,' boasts magnificent architectural wonders like the Semper Opera House, Royal Palace, Cathedral St. Trinitatis, Castle Pillnitz, and Frauenkirche. Despite the devastation of World War II, Dresden has persevered and regained its beauty.

sources.snippet: Our rating of ‚ÄúInteresting places in Dresden‚Äù is rightly headed by the Baroque masterpiece. At one time jousting tournaments were held in the Zwinger, and the lords of Saxony held lavish celebrations here. The present-day appearance of this Dresden landmark is that of a palace museum, whose many halls hold unique exhibits: weapons, paintings, porcelain objects, etc.
sources.shortName: Top 20 places to visit in Dresden in 2024 (Lots of photos)

sources.snippet: The Zwinger is to this day one of the most incredible baroque buildings in Germany. It was built for Augustus II the Strong, who had been inspired by King Louis XIV. He had returned from a visit to his new court of Versaille and was eager to create a similar elaborate palace for himself. But this was would be located in his hometown of Dresden.
sources.siteName: The Creative Adventurer - A Travel Guide for Exploring the World
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany
17 Photos of Dresden That‚Äôll Make You Want to Visit Today (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: The Zwinger is a palace complex full of gardens and is completely free to enter and walk around. You can wander around and get lost as you like. It was built for Augustus II. He had returned from a visit to his new court of Versailleand was eager to create a similar elaborate palace for himself in Dresden.
sources.siteName: | Just a girl and the world
sources.shortName: Instagrammable photos spots around Dresden, Germany |

sources.snippet: It is a building complex with an amazing garden and one of the most important buildings of the Baroque. It is located close to the Frauenkirche, which is the most famous monument in Dresden. Zwinger is a synthesis of art: from architecture and sculpture to painting...
sources.shortName: What to do in Dresden

sources.snippet: Located in Dresden Mitte just a ten-minute walk from the Zwinger, it‚Äôs a nice escape for anyone looking to get away from the tourist crowds and sip a cup of joe in peace. Built in the old gatehouse of the city powerplant, it‚Äôs decor is chic 1930‚Äôs simplicity.
sources.siteName: History Fangirl - The Ultimate History Travel Blog Since 2015
sources.shortName: 17 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

places.name: Dresden Zwinger

reviews.text:
The building is still under construction üöß and the garden also.
But it's still beautiful, they allowed tourists to go inside the garden for free and walking up to the fortress area to see the view on both sides of the castle and city.
The beautiful historical arts and history is worth to visit, very close to the Opera House too.

The Dresden Zwinger is no doubt a masterpiece of Baroque architecture and one of the city's absolute highlights. Walking through its elegant courtyards feels like stepping back in time. The symmetry, the sculptures, the fountains-it's all so grand and beautifully preserved but it's under construction right now.

Magnificent Baroque palace, initially build by August Strong as a an orangery and gardens, destroyed by the ally bombings in 1945, restored in 50s and 60s .
You can walk on the roof of the galleries and admire the beauty of it. It's open till late evening and the entrance is free.The inner garden part is currently ( as of August 2025)  under renovation.
The galleries house 2 museums  - one of mathematical instruments and another is porcelain gallery ( which I highly recommend).
When we were there in one of the towers a classical music concert was held. It was beautiful to listen to music in a such beautiful place.

places.generalDescription: The Frauenkirche Dresden is a stunning Baroque church that was reconstructed and reconsecrated in 2005 after being destroyed during World War II. It is part of the magnificent architectural ensemble in Dresden, often referred to as 'The Florence on the Elbe,' which includes the Semper Opera House, Zwinger, Royal Palace, Cathedral St. Trinitatis (Hofkriche), and Castle Pillnitz.

sources.snippet: Symbolising the city of Dresden itself, the Frauenkirche, or Lady‚Äôs Church, rose from the ashes when it was rebuilt after it was bombed in 1945. However, it‚Äôs an exact replica of the original Lutheran church and visitors love the splendour of the octagonal hall and ornate altar. Climb up to the 67m (220ft) high viewing platform of the stone dome ‚Äì it is well worth the effort as it offers unrivalled views over Dresden.
sources.shortName: The Top Things To See And Do In Dresden

sources.snippet: Dresden's spectacular Frauenkirche is one of the most remarkable reconstruction projects ever to have taken place in Germany, if not the world. Completed in 1743, the spectacular Baroque original was considered one of the most beautiful churches in Europe. After its destruction during Allied bombing in 1945, the ruins of the old building were cataloged and stored for use in its reconstruction.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Dresden

sources.snippet: The most impressive building in Dresden, also known as the Church of our Lady, is Frauenkirche. It sits in the centre of Dresden Altstadt about a 20minute walk away from the central station. It was originally built in the 18th century, and after its destruction its ruins served as a memorial to the war.
sources.siteName: | Just a girl and the world
sources.shortName: Instagrammable photos spots around Dresden, Germany |

sources.snippet: This church is the main landmark of the city and it is full of history. Frauenkirche is a Baroque Protestant-Lutheran church and the most important monument in Neumarkt. During the Second World War, it was heavily damaged during the air raids on Dresden and the reconstruction continued till 2005.
sources.shortName: What to do in Dresden
17 Photos of Dresden That‚Äôll Make You Want to Visit Today (2024 Guide)

sources.snippet: Frauenkirche: The Frauenkirche is a beautiful Protestant church located in the heart of Dresden‚Äôs Old Town. It was destroyed during World War II, but it was rebuilt in the 1990s and is now a symbol of peace and reconciliation.
sources.shortName: Dresden Travel Guide ‚Ä¢ Best Places for Photography in Dresden

sources.snippet: The catholic hofkirche was built by Saxon ruler Augustus III in the 18th century as a counterweight for the protestant Frauenkirche. The Baroque church is one of the most beautiful buildings in Dresden.
sources.shortName: 22 Top Tourist Attractions in Dresden, Germany (+Map)
Top 20 places to visit in Dresden in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Frauenkirche Dresden

reviews.text: Dresden is a city to definitely see once in a life time.  I city out of a movie scene.  Beautiful at every corner.  Very impressive and not too be missed for sure.

This church is majestic and feels like a center piece of the city. The surrounding area with the church makes this place very picturesque. There is a called rubble from the past that is kept next to the church which is a nice little touch. This is definitely a must visit site in Dresden

We visited as it's our last day, it's pretty impressive how much money, time, and effort to rebuild all these historic buildings, including this Church of our Lady.
Inside still haven't had much to see but still nice to  visit. Free entry but if you wish to climb up to the viewing tower over 100 steps then have a fee.

places.generalDescription: Situated in Dresden Old Town, the Semperoper is a renowned opera house known for its opulent interior and exceptional acoustics. Originally built in 1841 by architect Gottfried Semper, it has a rich history including destruction by fire in 1869 and bombing in 1945. Despite these setbacks, the opera house was rebuilt and continues to host spectacular performances. The 1,300-seat auditorium offers an intimate setting with excellent views from every seat.

sources.snippet: The starting point for almost every Dresden tour, it‚Äôs unlikely that you‚Äôll be in Dresden without ending up at the Theaterplatz, the square in front of the Zwinger and the Semperoper. In the middle of the square is the statue of King Johann, one of the Saxon kings who ruled from Dresden. You‚Äôll find that there are usually people in the square since this is a prominent meeting point, but I found there were opportunities to photograph the square without people just by being patient.
sources.siteName: History Fangirl - The Ultimate History Travel Blog Since 2015
sources.shortName: 17 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

sources.snippet: It is the opera house of the S√§chsische Staatskapelle Dresden (Saxon State Opera Dresden), which has a long historical tradition as court and state opera of Saxony. The ensemble of the Semperoper is the traditional S√§chsische Staatskapelle Dresden. It is named after its architect Gottfried Semper.
sources.shortName: What to do in Dresden

sources.snippet: Located between the Zwinger and the Royal Palace, the Semperoper (Opera House) can be found towards the Western end of Br√ºhl‚Äôs Terrace. It‚Äôs the home of the Saxon State Opera, the Orchestra, and the Ballet. It‚Äôs yet another building that mostly destroyed during WWII and rebuilt.
sources.siteName: | Just a girl and the world
sources.shortName: Instagrammable photos spots around Dresden, Germany |

sources.snippet: Semperoper: The Semperoper is a world-renowned opera house that is home to the Saxon State Opera and the Dresden State Orchestra. It was originally built in 1841, but it was destroyed during World War II and was later rebuilt.
sources.shortName: Dresden Travel Guide ‚Ä¢ Best Places for Photography in Dresden

places.name: Semperoper Dresden

reviews.text: One of the most beautiful opera houses in the world! The orchestra was top rated and the acoustics amazing! Even if you are visiting Berlin you must give it a try!
Great architecture! Just minutes away from Dresden Old Town, Frauenkirchen, and much more.

Very impressive building, both interior as well as exterior-wise.
If you are an opera-fan, than you definitely have to visit this place.
We decided to attend it on short notice, hence only seats with very restrictive were left, but to buy well in advance.

Still very much recommendable!

places.generalDescription: Br√ºhl's Terrace, also known as the "balcony of Europe," is a Renaissance terrace in Dresden that offers stunning views of the Elbe River and beautiful architecture. Originally part of the city's fortifications, it was transformed into a terraced garden open to the public in 1814.

sources.snippet: Nicknamed the Balcony of Europe, Br√ºhl‚Äôs Terrace was once the ramparts of a fort built to protect the city. Now, the fortification has been replaced by a beautiful garden and the terrace serves as a promenade, offering incredible views of the river. Four sculpture groups on the staircase represent morning, noon and night.
sources.shortName: The Top Things To See And Do In Dresden

sources.snippet: It is an enormous platform that stretches along the shores of the Elbe River. While it was once used to protect the city from invaders, during Dresden‚Äôs rebuild it was transformed into a picturesque promenade for visitors to explore, stroll around, and enjoy the vibrant flowers during the spring. It‚Äôs also a popular spot for the Christmas Markets (Weihnachtsmarkt) during the festive season!
sources.siteName: | Just a girl and the world
sources.shortName: Instagrammable photos spots around Dresden, Germany |

sources.snippet: Nicknamed the Balcony of Europe, this is a great spot to people watch and enjoy the view of the Elbe river over the Neustadt. While most come to sit on Br√ºhl Terrace to enjoy the view, I love photographs of the actual terrace itself. Regardless of which photos you are more interested in, this is one of the most coveted photography spots in Dresden.
sources.siteName: History Fangirl - The Ultimate History Travel Blog Since 2015
sources.shortName: 17 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

sources.snippet: It is an enormous platform that stretches along the shores of the Elbe River. Here you‚Äôll see both tourists and locals alike, strolling down the promenade enjoying the fantastic views. The terrace was once built as a fort to protect the city from invaders, but in the 19th century, it was transformed into this lovely pedestrian walkway.
sources.siteName: The Creative Adventurer - A Travel Guide for Exploring the World
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

sources.snippet: The Balcony of Europe or Bruhl‚Äôs Terrace is half a thousand meters between the Karoly and Augustus bridges. When you come here, you can enjoy the enchanting landscapes of the city and the River Elbe. In addition, there are many restaurants and museums on this stretch of the promenade.
sources.shortName: Top 20 places to visit in Dresden in 2024 (Lots of photos)

sources.snippet: Br√ºhl‚Äôs Terrace: This beautiful promenade along the Elbe River offers fantastic views of the city and the river. It‚Äôs a popular spot for tourists, but early morning or late evening provides a quieter atmosphere for photographers.
sources.shortName: Dresden Travel Guide ‚Ä¢ Best Places for Photography in Dresden

places.name: Br√ºhl's Terrace

reviews.text: Br√ºhl's Terrace felt like the perfect place to slow down and take in Dresden's beauty. From my perspective, it's where the city opens up-offering stunning views of the Elbe River, historic buildings, and a peaceful atmosphere despite being in the middle of town. It's great for a scenic walk, especially around sunset, and there's a real sense of history all around you.

Fun terrace and great viewing platform to see the Elbe and the city as a whole. Great point in the city to figure out where to head next, amazing architecture with some beautiful flowers and fountains. You may even be able to find a chimney cake!

It's not called The Balcony of Europe for nothing.
Breathtaking place to spend some time admiring the views and peace watching.
Very positive energy.

places.generalDescription: Dresden Castle, also known as the Royal Palace, has a rich history dating back over 600 years. Despite being heavily damaged during World War II, it was meticulously rebuilt and now houses the Historic Green Vault, the New Green Vault, and various museums within the Dresden State Art Collections. The castle's architecture showcases a blend of styles including Baroque and Neo-Renaissance, with an iconic domed courtyard adorned with Renaissance-style sgraffito paintings.

sources.snippet: Dresden Castle: The Dresden Castle is a beautiful Renaissance palace that was the residence of the Saxon kings. It houses several museums, including the Green Vault, which contains one of the world‚Äôs largest collections of treasures.
sources.shortName: Dresden Travel Guide ‚Ä¢ Best Places for Photography in Dresden

places.name: Residenzschloss

reviews.text: Dresden Castle is absolutely incredible! The mix of history, stunning architecture, and insane collections inside makes it a must visit. The intricate details of the building itself are just next level, and the museums inside, especially the Green Vault, are mind blowing. You get to see royal treasures, crazy detailed jewelry, and so much history packed into one place.

Absolutely crowded, tour path is dictated and  it is difficult to manoeuvre. While the renovation is impressive it is difficult to gain a sense of the majesty. However it is a must visit. Queue patiently for photo opportunities as many wish for the same picture. A walk through the Marais is definitely required afterwards to see the many less crowded and beautiful places.

An excellent collection of precious objects, historical costumes, armor, weapons, coins, etc. However, part of the collection requires an additional ticket, and another part of the collection (the private quarters of the Saxon royals) was closed down without any warning. Also get tickets ahead of time or be prepared to wait a while in line.

places.generalDescription: Nestled just 15 kilometers northwest of Dresden, Moritzburg Castle is a stunning Baroque masterpiece that captivates visitors with its enchanting architecture and serene surroundings. Originally built as a hunting lodge for Augustus the Strong, this majestic castle features four distinctive round towers and houses an impressive collection of paintings, ceramics, and hunting trophies. The picturesque grounds surrounding the castle provide a perfect backdrop for leisurely strolls after exploring its opulent interiors.

sources.shortName: Top 20 places to visit in Dresden in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Moritzburg Castle

reviews.text:
Definitely worth to visit! The inside as well as the gardens are stunning.
Better to come here in the morning to avoid the crowds on the parking lot. There are two parking areas. One just in front of the palace and the other one from the back (5 min walk from the palace). Parking is 1,50‚Ç¨ per hour.

One of the best museum experiences I have ever had. I highly recommend taking the tour inside the castle, and I guarantee that you will not regret it. The museum is greatly managed, thanks to the staff. Upon buying a ticket, you will be provided with a tablet that you can use to get a virtual reality experience of the place during the time of August the Strong! We went on a Sunday and were the last ones to enter. The staff patiently waited for us until we were done with our tour.

This beautifully symmetrical palace, nestled in the middle of a man-made lake, exudes a charming yellow and white exterior that pays homage to the local style. Step inside and embark on a journey through time, exploring the palace's rich history and the fascinating artifacts it houses. Take a leisurely stroll around the palace to capture a breathtaking 360-degree view, which won't take much of your time. On the right side of the palace, you'll find a staircase leading up to a hidden gem: a metal Cinderella shoe! This palace was the filming location for the Czech version of Cinderella, and ladies are welcome to try on the iconic sandal. Men might even want to give it a shot! This charming castle is a perfect destination for a quick and enjoyable visit.

places.generalDescription: In Dresden, Saxony, one of the most captivating attractions is the F√ºrstenzug, also known as the Procession of Princes. This impressive 102-meter-long mural made of 23,000 Meissen porcelain tiles showcases the history of the House of Wettin, spanning from the 12th to the 19th century.

sources.snippet: The F√ºrstenzug (Procession of Princes) of Dresden is a large picture of a cavalcade, applied to around 23,000 tiles from Meissen porcelain. The 102-meter long piece of art, considered to be the largest porcelain mural in the world, represents the ancestral gallery of the 34 margraves, dukes, electors and kings, who ruled between 1127 and 1873 in Saxony. Since F√ºrstenzug is located on the outer wall of the Stallhof of Dresden Castle, the entrance is free.
sources.shortName: What to do in Dresden

sources.snippet: One of the most famous landmarks in the city, no trip to Dresden is complete without standing in awe beneath the F√ºrstenzug. This porcelain wall was commissioned in the nineteenth century to celebrate eight hundred years of rule by the Saxon Wettin dynasty. During the bombing of Dresden, the wall escaped mostly undamaged, so it is also one of the most important surviving historical sites in the Altstadt.
sources.siteName: History Fangirl - The Ultimate History Travel Blog Since 2015
sources.shortName: 17 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

sources.snippet: Along Schlo√üstra√üe, you‚Äôll find one of the greatest remnants of old Dresden, F√ºrstenzug or the Procession of Princes. Surprisingly, this mural survived the bombings of WWII and suffered minimal damage. Today, it‚Äôs the world‚Äôs largest porcelain artwork and was first installed in 1871 after taking five years to complete.
sources.siteName: | Just a girl and the world
sources.shortName: Instagrammable photos spots around Dresden, Germany |

places.name: F√ºrstenzug

reviews.text: The F√ºrstenzug in Dresden is an impressive mural made of Meissen porcelain tiles, depicting the history of Saxon rulers. At over 100 meters long, it is one of the largest porcelain artworks in the world. The level of detail in the figures is truly fascinating, bringing history to life. A must-see historical landmark when visiting Dresden!

The F√ºrstenzug took me by surprise-so detailed and grand, yet tucked along a quiet street. From my perspective, it's one of those places that really brings history to life. The scale and craftsmanship of the porcelain mural are incredible, and it's amazing how well it's been preserved. It's definitely worth pausing here while exploring the old town-it doesn't take long, but it leaves a lasting impression.

the procession of princes is enormous 102-meter-long porcelain mural that basically tells the history of saxony. it features 94 figures of all the saxon rulers and nobles in chronological order, starting way back in 1127.
what's really cool is that it's made from an incredible 25,000 meissen porcelain tiles, which makes it the world's largest porcelain artwork. you'll find it right on augustusstra√üe, so it's super easy to check out as you're walking between dresden's main attractions. and the best part? you can view it completely free

places.generalDescription: The Dresden Panometer is a unique attraction located in the Reick district, to the southwest of Dresden's city center. Created by Austrian artist Yadegar Asisi, this site features a massive 360¬∞ panoramic painting housed within a disused telegraphic gasometer. The panoramic image measures 27 meters in height and 127 meters in circumference, providing visitors with an immersive experience of Dresden's past.

sources.snippet: It is a former gas tank: here, since 2006, various panoramic images of the Austrian artist Yadegar Asisi have been exhibited. The artist's circular paintings are drawn at a height of 27 meters. Two of the famous panoramas represent Dresden in 1756, which shows the capital of Saxony at the time of the Dresden Baroque, and Dresden in 1945, a reflection of the destroyed city during the Second World War.
sources.shortName: What to do in Dresden

sources.snippet: Dresden Panometer: The Dresden Panometer is a unique attraction that features a 360-degree panoramic view of Dresden during the Baroque period. The exhibit is housed in a former gasometer and is an immersive experience that takes you back in time.
sources.shortName: Dresden Travel Guide ‚Ä¢ Best Places for Photography in Dresden

sources.snippet: Get to know Dresden‚Äôs architecture and city art on an intimate level with a voice-guided tour in the most unique way. This extraordinary audio-visual experience will surround you with lights and take you to a Dresden of the past.
sources.shortName: 22 Top Tourist Attractions in Dresden, Germany (+Map)

places.name: Dresden Panometer

reviews.text:
Not always the same show is there. I visited the Amazon show by Yadegar Azizi. I enjoyed how deeply I felt being at Amazon.

I wished we could also feel a bit the Amazon's weather.

Interesting location, old gas warehouses... Now renovated into a museum. Excellent content, well presented - the Amazon was on the program. Parking and city transport are nearby, everything is organized. There is a cafe and toilet inside. Expensive entrance fee for a good hour and a half tour...

Highly recommended to see a panorama view of the old town of Dresden.

Pretty nice exhibition, with great stories of Dresden's history. Love all the details they have, including the detailed stories happening at the moment, the change between day and nights, and the music.
Also really cool to see how Dresden has preserved how the city looks throughout all these years!

Lastly, deeply amazed by how the artist leveraged the gas storage building that's no longer in use as the perfect location to show the artwork!

places.generalDescription: The Old Masters Picture Gallery is a must-visit for art enthusiasts, featuring an impressive collection of European art from the 16th to 18th centuries. The gallery houses renowned works by Raphael, Rembrandt, Vermeer, and other masters such as Titian, Tintoretto, Holbein, Durer, and Cranach.

sources.snippet: Dresden's spectacular Frauenkirche is one of the most remarkable reconstruction projects ever to have taken place in Germany, if not the world. Completed in 1743, the spectacular Baroque original was considered one of the most beautiful churches in Europe. After its destruction during Allied bombing in 1945, the ruins of the old building were cataloged and stored for use in its reconstruction.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Dresden

sources.snippet: The Gem√§ldegalerie Alte Meister (or Old Masters Gallery) is honestly the best art gallery I ever had the pleasure of visiting. It doesn‚Äôt feel too big nor too small. It‚Äôs like a grand old home that someone has decorated with exquisite pieces of arts ‚Äî a stellar collection that‚Äôs lovingly curated.
sources.siteName: The Creative Adventurer - A Travel Guide for Exploring the World
sources.shortName: The Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

places.name: SKD | Old Masters Picture Gallery

reviews.text:
Old Masters Gallery in Dresden is a world class collection of paintings from a period spanning 15th to 18th centuries. It is a must-visit museum which is very professionally run. In my first visit, my primary motivation was to see the Dresden Triptych by the master Flemish painter Jan Van Eyck (this is one of the few -about 20- remaining paintings by him). It is truly breathtaking to see how much painterly skill he had. Understandably, they keep it under a glass enclosure. After the first one,  I visited this museum a few more times.

Overall, it is a unique collection with many great artists (Rembrandt, Vermeer, Holbein the younger, Ribera, Titian etc.) and paintings to choose as favorites. But the real suprise for me was to see the 18th century veduta paintings (cityscapes) by Bernardo Bellotto. The detail and precision with which he captured Dresden and the surrounding provinces is remarkable. As someone who loves landscape paintings and is a fan of Claude Lorrain, John Constable and Joseph Mallord William Turner (each had very distinct styles, of course), it was such a pleasant suprise to discover an artist like Belotto.

I will definitely come back!

The Gem√§ldegalerie Dresden is truly a treasure that has emerged from the shadows of history, often referred to as the "Sleeping Beauty" during the communist era. Despite being overlooked for so long, this painting gallery has been beautifully rediscovered and now stands proudly among its esteemed peers like the Uffizi, Prado, the National Gallery and others. Since its establishment in 1746, the gallery has offered an extraordinary collection of masterpieces that captivate art lovers and casual visitors alike. The rich history of the gallery, coupled with its stunning exhibits, makes it an absolute excellence in Dresden. Whether you're an art aficionado or just looking for a cultural experience, the Gem√§ldegalerie is a must-visit. It's a powerful reminder of the resilience of art and culture, and a testament to Dresden's commitment to preserving its artistic heritage. Don't miss the chance to experience this magnificent collection! Support it becoming a member of the association MUSEIS SAXONICIS USUI!

My lifelong dream to visit the Dresden Gallery of Old Masters finally came true.
I spent almost whole day admiring the amazing art presented in the galleries, and it was enough.  Even though the OMG is not as overwhelmingly big as let's say MET or Louvre one can easily spend 2-3 days here.
Rubens, Titian, Botticelli, Cranach to name a few, and there are much more of Dutch, Germany, Italian masters.
Please come and enjoy.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Dresden's old town, the Kathedrale Sanctissimae Trinitatis stands as a stunning example of late Baroque architecture, crafted by the talented Gaetano Chiaveri between 1739 and 1755. This remarkable structure features an impressive tower that reaches 85.5 meters high and is adorned with 78 statues of saints gracing its balustrades.

sources.snippet: This cathedral, also known as the Catholic Court Church, is found between Schlossplatz and Theaterplatz, and is Saxony's largest ecclesiastical building. It was built by Chiaveri between 1738 and 1754 in the Baroque style. Since 1980 it has been the cathedral of the Dresden-Meissen diocese.
sources.shortName: Top Ten | Landeshauptstadt Dresden

places.name: Cathedral St. Trinitatis

reviews.text:
Magnificent cathedral, beautifully restored inside and out!

It is not a massive building but if you take your time to looking for details, it will amaze you for sure!

The church are closed for lunch between 12:00 noon to one PM everyday. And the door D will open right at the bell ring at 1:00 pm.

Take your time, seats down and enjoy this amazing masterpiece!

the dresden cathedral (hofkirche) is a beautiful baroque church right by the castle and zwinger, super easy to visit. its exterior has impressive saint statues, and inside you'll find treasures like the historic silbermann organ. entrance is free, it's very peaceful, and it's cool to know saxon kings (including augustus the strong's heart) are buried in the crypt. a quick, interesting stop
Lovely cathedral next to Bruhl terrace and across from the opera house. Free to enter with a stunning interior.

places.generalDescription: The Loschwitz Bridge, also known as the "Blue Wonder," is a historic steel bridge that crosses the Elbe River and connects the districts of Blasewitz and Loschwitz in Dresden. Built in the late 19th century, it was a remarkable engineering achievement at the time. The bridge offers stunning views of the river and surrounding villas, making it a popular spot for pedestrians, motorists, and cyclists.

sources.snippet: This industrial-looking nineteenth century bridge survived the bombing. It‚Äôs blue color is the stuff of legends, with many popular stories about how it got its color being complete fabrications. You can photograph it from the land, but it also looks great from a river cruise.
sources.siteName: History Fangirl - The Ultimate History Travel Blog Since 2015
sources.shortName: 17 of the Most Instagrammable Places in Dresden, Germany

sources.snippet: A landmark also known as the ‚ÄúBlue Wonder‚Äù (the name was given by the unusual shape and coloring of the structure). The structure stands on the bank of the river on two piers. The width and length of the bridge is 12 meters and 280 meters respectively.
sources.shortName: Top 20 places to visit in Dresden in 2024 (Lots of photos)

places.name: Loschwitz Bridge

reviews.text: Great bridge, worth to see. Very nice area around with restaurants.
Blasewitz district is elegant, you can walk in Elbe side. There are restaurants and cafes around, really recommended
The Blue Wonder Bridge on the way to Pillnitz Castle: known as Blaues Wunder. Such a beautiful area near the Elbe River. One can catch ferry to Pillnitz Castle from here.

places.generalDescription: Albertinum is a grand 19th-century building housing an art museum that showcases New Masters and contemporary works, along with sculptures. It is one of the must-see attractions in Dresden, offering a rich cultural experience. The museum features spectacular paintings, crafted art, and porcelain creations. Visitors can admire works by renowned artists such as Edgar Degas, Paul Gaugin, and Claude Monet at the New Masters Gallery within Albertinum.

sources.snippet: Born in Dresden in 1932, artist Gerhard Richter was fortunate that he was too young to fight in World War II. However, the hardship of Nazi period, including the war years and their aftermath, shaped him and his work. Dresden‚Äôs New Masters Gallery (Galerie Neue Meisters) in the Albertinum museum holds the Richter Archive, and shows a selection from this modern master. There are also works by Monet, Caspar David Friedrich and Degas, among other art greats.
sources.shortName: The Top Things To See And Do In Dresden

sources.snippet: Built between 1884 and 1887, the Renaissance Revival Albertinum on Br√ºhl's Terrace is as spectacular as the world-class art collection it houses. The museum is best known for its impressive New Masters Gallery, with its rich collection of works of the Romantic and Realist periods, as well as French, Polish, Romanian, Hungarian, and Belgian paintings of the 19th century and German Impressionists and Expressionists.
sources.shortName: Attractions & Things to Do in Dresden

sources.snippet: On the northeast side of Old Town sits the Albertinum, a grand art museum famous for its large Renaissance building. Named after King Albert of Saxony, the building was once used as an armory before being redesigned by the regional master builder Carl Adolf Canzler in the 16th century.
sources.shortName: 22 Top Tourist Attractions in Dresden, Germany (+Map)

sources.snippet: Albertinum: The Albertinum is an art museum that houses a collection of modern and contemporary art, as well as works by famous artists such as Caspar David Friedrich and Gerhard Richter.
sources.shortName: Dresden Travel Guide ‚Ä¢ Best Places for Photography in Dresden

places.name: Albertinum (1884-87; Adolph Canzler)

reviews.text: The Albertinum in Dresden is an absolute must-visit for art lovers! The museum's collection is impressive, showcasing a mix of classic and modern art that offers something for everyone. The layout is well thought out, making it easy to navigate and fully enjoy each piece. The building itself is beautiful, and the location right by the river adds to the experience. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, and there's a relaxed atmosphere that makes it easy to take your time and really soak in the art. Highly recommended if you're in Dresden!
Wonderful gallery right in the center of Dresden. Especially the top floor which contains art from 19th century and onwards. If you find yourself in Dresden then Albertinum is a must see.

This museum boasts varieties of amazing collections from the 19th century to the present. Most paintings and sculptures have no protections or fences so it might be difficult to visit here with very small children. I myself really enjoyed the exhibition and would like to come back again!

places.generalDescription: The Golden Rider is a renowned gilded equestrian statue located in the Neustadt district of Dresden. It depicts King August II, dressed as a Roman Caesar, riding a horse and covered in gold leaf. The statue was commissioned by his son and inaugurated in 1734. As you explore Dresden, this iconic monument is one of the first sights to behold when crossing the August Bridge into Neustadt.

sources.snippet: Glistening in the mid-day sun, the Golden Rider stands tall in the middle of a large stone brick courtyard. Unlike many famous bronze statues that have since lost their shine, this gold platelet monolith of King August II shimmers on.
sources.shortName: 22 Top Tourist Attractions in Dresden, Germany (+Map)

places.name: Golden Rider

reviews.text: Loved the statue-view, the ambience, and the nearby garden. Saw and a street singer singing her heart out in English (English Songs): loved the voice and song selection. Serene environment to sit on benches and shop on nearby shops. A must visit place in Dresden, Germany

The golden monument. I went here in the summer, the sun was very strong, the air was hot and humid because it is an outdoor monument. The surrounding area is a billion times wide. Behind the monument is a long park that runs all the way to the end of the road. People come out to relax. There are many ice cream shops to choose from.

Beautiful place on the banks of the river Elbe to have a (for German standards rather expensive) beer with an amazing view on the historic city.
The restrooms behind the bar are public and charge you 0.5 EUR extra to use them! Also, for the price you would expect table service but it's self service. The seating is shaded and it's less crowded then the beer garden on the other side of the bridge.

places.generalDescription: The Museum of Military History, located in an 1870s arsenal with a modern extension by Daniel Libeskind, offers a unique opportunity to delve into the military history of Dresden. The museum showcases exhibits from the Navy Force and Air Force, as well as ancient combat equipment such as shields, spears, swords, and daggers. Situated across the Elbe River in Neustadt (New Town), the museum's avant-garde architecture is a sight to behold.

sources.snippet: The Bundeswehr Military History Museum is fabulous to get a handle on warfare in general, but also on German military history. It recently received a stylish update from star architect Daniel Liebeskind. Recommended by Paul Wheatley
sources.shortName: The Top Things To See And Do In Dresden

sources.snippet: If the nitty-gritty details of historical warfare are more your speed, then the expansive Dresden Bundeswehr Museum of Military History is a stop you won‚Äôt want to miss. Here you can explore Germany‚Äôs past and learn how machines of war led to human advancement in the world of engineering.
sources.shortName: 22 Top Tourist Attractions in Dresden, Germany (+Map)

places.name: Museum of Military History

reviews.text: Really great place to visit lots to see and explore. Theres 5 floors in total and we took hours just to clear one floor. Had to rush off to our next destination so that was a pity. Really clean and quiet museum with quite alot of people. But we still get alot of space to explore on our own. Loved the experience including the outdoor exhibits of old tankers and military vehicles. Highly recommend dropping by when you have time

A good museum of the German army. Organized, but there is a little too little emphasis on the period of both world wars and too few large and important exhibits. There is a parking lot right next to it and also city transport. You need about 2-3 hours for the entire tour. I recommend it.

A good experience, definitely worth the price. There seems to be a problem with the lighting and some areas are not properly lit so you have to really try to read the descriptions and that was a little annoying. Also you may need more than 3 hours to see the whole thing.
